Documentation.name: Enexis ECDM
Documentation.notes: Incorporates the ECDM Profile, diagram and toolbox. Enhanced for REST- and CM functionality, Various enhancements. 4.4: Added RESTResponseCodeCollection 4.5: Added Service.CMTicketID

Documentation.name: Enexis ECDM
Documentation.notes: 20170918: Vs 3.0: Enhanced Service Profile for use with REST. 20180109: Vs 3.1: Added support for 'nillable' elements. 20180110: Vs 3.2: Added 'alternativeNaming' tag to CommonSchema (SOAP backwards compatibility). 20180213: Vs 3.3: Defines Service Archtetype and added _metatype to Service. 20180216: Vs 3.4: Resource: removed 'isTag', added 'tagNames'. 20180308: Vs 4.0: Implemented first draft of the Configuration Management Profile. 20180620: Vs 4.1: Added another state to Service CM state: CheckedOut. 20180815: Vs 4.2: Added CM Ticket 20180913: Vs.4.3: Moved Representation Term to upper metadata. 20181220: Vs 4.4: Added the RESTResponseCodeCollection. 20190114: Vs 4.5: Added Service.CMTicketID

Stereotype.name: ASMBIE
Stereotype.notes: Association Message Business Information Entity.

Stereotype.name: BDT
Stereotype.notes: This stereotype is used to qualify a data type as a Business Data Type according to UN/CEFACT CCTS.

Stereotype.name: BDTComplexType
Stereotype.notes: Business Data Type, Complex Type

Stereotype.name: BDTEnumeration
Stereotype.notes: Business Data Type, Enumeration

Stereotype.name: BDTModel
Stereotype.notes: The Business Data Type library is used to define reusable business-aware data type that are used as attributes in business components.

Stereotype.name: BDTSimpleType
Stereotype.notes: Business Data Type, Simple Type

Stereotype.name: BDTUnion
Stereotype.notes: Business Data Type, Union

Stereotype.name: BusinessComponent
Stereotype.notes: Aggregated Business Information Entity (ABIE), reusable business component (business context)

Stereotype.name: CCMA
Stereotype.notes: UN/CEFACT Core Component Message Assembly

Stereotype.name: CCModel
Stereotype.notes: Core Component Library is used for reusable, business-agnostic components (Aggregate Core Components, or ACC, in UN/CEFACT CCTS 'speak'

Stereotype.name: CDT
Stereotype.notes: This stereotype is used to qualify a data type as a Core Data Type according to UN/CEFACT CCTS

Stereotype.name: CDTComplexType
Stereotype.notes: Core Data Type, Complex Type.

Stereotype.name: CDTModel
Stereotype.notes: This stereotype is 'reserved' for qualification of the Core Data Type library, of which there must be at most ONE within the framework!

Stereotype.name: CDTSimpleType
Stereotype.notes: Core Data Type, Simple Type

Stereotype.name: CLE
Stereotype.notes: Defines a single element (enumeration) within a code list (CLE = CodeListElement).

Stereotype.name: CodeLists
Stereotype.notes: Indicates that this package contains Code List definitions according to UN/CEFACT CCTS. Code Lists are enumerated types that are transformed into stand-alone schema files that can be used to exchange sets of definitions without the limitations of a fixed schema.

Stereotype.name: CommonSchema
Stereotype.notes: This is a capability for storage of all common types that are used by the service operations. Typically, a service has a single common schema associated with it, which facilitates central storage of common types, thereby reducing overhead of the operation schema's.

Tag.name: fileName
Tag.description: Contains the associated schema name WITHOUT the path name.

Tag.name: pathName
Tag.description: Contains the absolute pathname to the schema file.

Tag.name: nsToken
Tag.description: Stores the namespace mnemonic name.

Tag.name: useAlternativeNaming
Tag.description: Set this tag to 'true' to force the 'original' naming convention for the Common Namespace. This implies that the name of the schema is changed to "Common" (instead of "CommonSchema") and the namespace will not include the container name. This results in a naming convention that is compatible with the original plugin (and which is inherently wrong because it might lead to naming conflicts). The option is included to facilitate backwards compatibility for SOAP services.

Stereotype.name: Content
Stereotype.notes: This stereotype must be be used to mark an attribute as "regular content" of a type. These are typically translated into XSD 'Elements'.

Tag.name: nillable
Tag.description: When present and set to 'true', this indicates that implementations can specify the value of the attribute as 'NULL'. This is typically used only in XSD/XML implementations.

Stereotype.name: CoreComponent
Stereotype.notes: Aggregate Core Component (ACC), reusable core component (no business context).

Stereotype.name: DEPRECATED
Stereotype.notes: This Stereotype is used to mark a particular element as Deprecated. Deprecated elements must NOT be used in API definitions!

Tag.name: Reason
Tag.description: Reason for deprecation

Tag.name: sequenceKey
Tag.description: The sequence key facilitates the construction of an order in a number of associations from one class to another. This key is typically used when defining the order of elements in a schema, generated from a model. Within a class, all attributes have pre-assigned sequence numbers starting from 100. For associations to 'fit' at a specific position, users must assign the appropriate value to this sequenceKey attribute.

Tag.name: propertyQualifierName
Tag.description: Is a word or words which help define and differentiate the property. The order in which the qualifiers are expressed indicate the order to be used, where the first one is to be the first order qualifier.

Tag.name: propertyTermName
Tag.description: Represents a distinguishing characteristic of the property that helps in uniquely defining the property.

Stereotype.name: ECDMChange
Stereotype.notes: This stereotype is used to mark an attribute, classifier or association as an ECDM change to an existing reference model. Since this is an extension of the NamedElement meta object, ECDMChange can be applied to most aspects of any model.

Tag.name: scope
Tag.description: Defines the scope of a profiled version of this component within an integration solution. Per profiled instance, the scope can be set to Service-, Operation- or Message level. The scope is defined as the uniqueness of the profiled component within the namespace of an integration solution.

Tag.name: dataTypeQualifierName
Tag.description: A word or words which help define and differentiate a Data Type. It further enhances the semantic meaning of the DataType. The order in which the qualifiers are expressed indicate the order to be used, where the first one is to be the first order qualifier.

Tag.name: useSupplementaries
Tag.description: If set to 'true', this indicates that supplementary attributes must be generated for output schemas (but only for the element for which this attribute is set to 'true').

Stereotype.name: ECDMMeta
Stereotype.notes: Root class for metaclass stereotypes.

Tag.name: displayName
Tag.description: An informal alternative name of the associated entity that can be used as a representation term.

Tag.name: businessTermName
Tag.description: One or more synonym terms under which the associated entity is commonly known and used in a business (in case multiple terms are used, these must be separated by commas).

Tag.name: definition
Tag.description: Semantic meaning of the associated entity.

Tag.name: dictionaryEntryName
Tag.description: The official and formal entity name as registered in a dictionary of terms (glossary).

Tag.name: uniqueID
Tag.description: An identifier that references the associated entity in a unique and unambiguous way.

Tag.name: representationTermName
Tag.description: An element of the entity name that describes the form in which the entity is represented. Typically, this represents the data type of the entity (e.g. "Numeric", "Text", "Code", "Binary Object", "Customer" or "Address").

Tag.name: ticketID
Tag.description: Identifies the ticket number in the ticket management system, which is used to register the associated work.

Tag.name: projectOrderID
Tag.description: Identifies the project associated with the ticket.

Tag.name: creationTimestamp
Tag.description: Date and time of creation (ISO 8601 format) of the associated entity in the external ticket management system.

Tag.name: modificationTimestamp
Tag.description: Date and time of last modification/state-change (ISO 8601 format) of the associated entity.

Stereotype.name: ECDMRoot
Stereotype.notes: Used as placeholder for generic metadata.

Tag.name: reference
Tag.description: External reference containing additional information or context. Can be a pointer to an architecture artifact.

Stereotype.name: Facet
Stereotype.notes: The Facet stereotype is used to identify attributes that are used to describe a particular aspect or feature of a type. Facets are typically used to define constraints on primitive types such as minimum or maximum string length.

Tag.name: fileName
Tag.description: Used to store the name of the contract file (typically, a WSDL). WITHOUT pathname.

Tag.name: pathName
Tag.description: Absolute path to associated filename.

Tag.name: accessLevel
Tag.description: Defines the level of confidentiality of the service interface capability. This typically is the most restrictive level defined by each of the associated operations.

Stereotype.name: LDT
Stereotype.notes: Logical Data Type. This qualifier is used by the message generation tools to detect data types and perform special operations on them. EN/CEFACT CCTS Core Data Types and Business Data Types are by definition Logical Data Types.

Stereotype.name: LOM
Stereotype.notes: The LOM stereotype indicates that this package represents a Logical Object Model (LOM). LOM packages consists of Business Components (ABIE in "UN/CEFACT speak").

Stereotype.name: LOMView
Stereotype.notes: The LOMView stereotype indicates that this package represents a specific view on one or more LOM models. Typically, LOM components reside in the ECDM Framework and are derived from reference models. LOMViews are specialized "snippets" of LOM classes, combined to model a specific business- or integration solution. A LOMView package shall only contain classes that are added to create a complete solution, but often will be empty (only a diagram exists that contains references to other package contents).

Stereotype.name: MBDT
Stereotype.notes: Message Business Data Type, is used to mark message-specific Business Data Types that are created specifically for use in a single service message.

Stereotype.name: MBIE
Stereotype.notes: Message Business Information Entity. This is a Business Component that has been profiled into a message or common schema of a service.

Tag.name: accessLevel
Tag.description: Defines the level of confidentiality that is applicable to the associated Operation Capability.

Tag.name: fileName
Tag.description: The name of the operation schema file (typically, an XSD). This is the name WITHOUT the path!

Tag.name: isInteractiveIndicator
Tag.description: Interactive operations are associated with a user session and must return information to that user within a reasonable period of time (e.g. within 1 or 2 seconds).

Tag.name: isRealtimeIndicator
Tag.description: Indicates that the service operation must interact with the source application within strict timing requirements. Real-time in this context must be interpreted as "operation will take place immediately".

Tag.name: isAsynchronousIndicator
Tag.description: This indicates that the operation is asynchronous, e.g. response will be returned at a later moment in time and through a different channel.

Tag.name: nsToken
Tag.description: Stores the operation's namespace mnemonic name.

Tag.name: operationID
Tag.description: Each Operation that is added to a Service receives a unique sequence number or operationID. In order to keep track of these ID's, the Service maintains the latest index used so far as 'maxOperationID'. OperationID's are never reclaimed, so when an Operation is removed, it's ID won't be re-used.

Tag.name: pathName
Tag.description: Contains the absolute path to the associated operation schema file (typically, an XSD).

Stereotype.name: PRIM
Stereotype.notes: This stereotype is used to qualify a data type as a Primitive Data Type according to UN/CEFACT CCTS.

Stereotype.name: PRIMEnumeration
Stereotype.notes: Primitive Enumeration.

Stereotype.name: PRIMModel
Stereotype.notes: This stereotype is 'reserved' for qualification of the Primitive Data Type library, of which there must be at most ONE within the framework!

Stereotype.name: PRIMSimpleType
Stereotype.notes: Primitive, Simple Type.

Stereotype.name: PRIMUnion
Stereotype.notes: Classification of Data Type. Union may only consist of Simple Types.

Stereotype.name: RESTFlow
Stereotype.notes: RESTFlow can have child flows and each flow contains a single Resource Collection class plus the associated Path Expressions and Resource Represenations that belong to that Collection class. All RESTFlows MUST be unique within a single API and Child RESTFlows must NOT be shared among parent flows!

Stereotype.name: RESTOperation
Stereotype.notes:
An Operation is associated with EITHER a PathExpression OR a ResourceCollection. In case of PathExpression, the operation receives the parameters from the Path. Additional parameters can be added by explicitly choosing them in the "Edit Operation" dialogue. Each parameter is an attribute of the Operation class with the appropriate stereotype (PathExpression attributes are considered part of the Operation even though they are not explicitly defined as such): PathParam, QueryParam, HeaderParam, FormParam, BodyParam.
Unlike SOAP operations, where an Operation is ALWAYS associated with a Business Message, RESTOperations are selectively associated with a Request- or Response payload through the use of an attribute with stereotype "BodyParam". In this case, the classifier is the 'aggregate root' of the message (i.e. the MessageAssembly).
Responses are created by inserting an attribute of which the name matches the HTTP response code. Type is optional but when specified, MUST be the 'aggregate root' of the response message (i.e. the MessageAssembly). Stereotype in this case is BodyParam. In case of HTTP Errors, the name is still the HTTP error code, but type must be 'none' and stereotype is ErrorParam.

Tag.name: useHeaderParameters
Tag.description: Set to 'true' to indicate that the operation uses configured Header Parameters.

Tag.name: useLinkHeaders
Tag.description: Set to 'true' to indicate that the operation response might use 'Link' header parameters.

Tag.name: consumesMIMEList
Tag.description: Comma separated list of MIME types that can be consumed by this operation.

Tag.name: producesMIMEList
Tag.description: Comma separated list of MIME types that can be produced through this operation.

Stereotype.name: RESTOperationResult
Stereotype.notes: Descriptor that defines a single result of a REST call. This is always assigned to an HTTP result code and may- or may not have a set of result parameters associated with the result Capability.

Tag.name: allowEmptyValue
Tag.description: When set to 'true', this indicates that the parameter is allowed to be specified by 'name only' (no value). This is only valid for Query or FormData parameters.

Stereotype.name: RESTResource
Stereotype.notes: The ECDM REST model builds an URL using the generic pattern <resource>/<path-expression>/<resource>/<path-expression>/<resource>... The role of each resource object within this URL is specified by the 'archetype' tag. The value of the tag is used to impose some validation and construction rules: 1) Document or Controller resources are allowed only at the end of the URL. 2) Collection or Store resources MUST always be followed by a Path Expression, i.e. they are NOT allowed at the end of the URL. 3) Path Expressions can ONLY be owned by a Collection or a Store.

Tag.name: isRootLevel
Tag.description: Set to TRUE of this is a root-level resource (otherwise known as 'sub-API'). Root-level resources are the first resources below the API major version in the URL.

Tag.name: tagNames
Tag.description: Comma separated list of all tag names assigned to this resource.

Stereotype.name: RESTResponseCodeCollection
Stereotype.notes: Classes of this type are helper classes, which are user defined and contain a set of response codes to be used for a specific REST API. By storing the response codes as a list of attributes in a Response Code Collection, the user only has to define response code once and can quickly apply a complete set of codes to a given operation.

Stereotype.name: Release
Stereotype.notes: Represents a formal release of one or more services (identified through a collection of associated features incorporated in the release).

Tag.name: version
Tag.description: Version number of the release. When a release is 'repeated' (i.e. because of last-minute changes and/or bugs), the release number is incremented for each subsequent release.

Stereotype.name: ReleaseMgmt
Stereotype.notes: Release Management association (associations between Tickets, Releases and Services)

Stereotype.name: SBDH
Stereotype.notes: Service Business Document Header, used to identify the standardised request- and response headers.

Tag.name: archetype
Tag.description: Defines the archetype of the Service.

Tag.name: maxOperationID
Tag.description: Each Operation that is added to a Service receives a unique sequence number or operationID. In order to keep track of these ID's, the Service maintains the latest index used so far as 'maxOperationID'. OperationID's are never reclaimed, so when an Operation is removed, it's ID won't be re-used.

Tag.name: CMBranch
Tag.description: Contains the name of the Configuration Management Branch on which the service is tracked.

Tag.name: CMTicketID
Tag.description: Contains the ID of the currently open ticket for this Service (if any).

Stereotype.name: ServiceCapability
Stereotype.notes: A service capability represents a functional component of a (web-)service. Different 'flavours' of capabilities exist that are used to define messages, operations, contracts, etc.

Stereotype.name: ServiceContainer
Stereotype.notes: A Service Container is a package in which a number of services are grouped together that serve a common functional domain. Typically, the service container represents an adapter for a data source.

Stereotype.name: ServiceDeclaration
Stereotype.notes: This is the root package that contains all the components that comprise a specific major version of a service.

Stereotype.name: Supplementary
Stereotype.notes: The Supplementary stereotype is used to mark an attribute as a supplementary attribute, which describe metadata of a type. These are typically translated to XSD 'Attributes'.

Tag.name: externalStatusCode
Tag.description: Ticket status in external ticket management system.

Tag.name: externalPriority
Tag.description: Priority assigned to the ticket in the external ticket management system.

Tag.name: releasedVersion
Tag.description: Service version (major.minor.build) associated with the ticket.

Tag.name: developmentRepositoryNS
Tag.description: Namespace of the associated development branch, MUST be in the same GitLab instance (same root URL).

Tag.name: developmentBranchName
Tag.description: Name of the branch used by development (required for generation of the appropriate merge request).

Stereotype.name: _ASBIE
Stereotype.notes: Association Business Information Entity, used to qualify the association between two Business Components (ABIE's).

Stereotype.name: _ASCC
Stereotype.notes: Association Core Component, used to qualify the association between two Core Components (ACC's).

Column.name: Description
Column.value: CodeList element name in particular source.

Stereotype.name: Business Data Types
Stereotype.notes: Create Business Data Type (BDT) definitions.

Stereotype.name: Logical Object Model
Stereotype.notes: Create a logical business model containing ABIE (Aggregate Business Information Entity) components.

Stereotype.name: Logical Object Model View
Stereotype.notes: A LOMView diagram contains a viewpoint on one or multiple Logical Object Models.

Stereotype.name: Package Model
Stereotype.notes: Create ECDM Package types

Documentation.name: Enexis ECDM
Documentation.notes: 26-08-2015: [1.0] Initial release. 18-09-2017: [2.0] Added support for REST 08-03-2018: [3.0] Added support for Configuration Management 15-08-2018: [4.2] Added CM Ticket 17-09-2018: [4.2] Added additional "sync" objects.

Stereotype.name: Business Components
Stereotype.notes: Create business components and data types

Stereotype.name: Component Relationships
Stereotype.notes: Create component connectors

Stereotype.name: Containers
Stereotype.notes: Create the correct package type for your diagram

Stereotype.name: EnexisECDM::DataTypes
Stereotype.notes: Select the correct data type to be created

Stereotype.name: SyncElements
Stereotype.notes: Create business components and data types
